awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites - Type I: Accelerating Innovation and Entrepreneurial Development at University of California, Santa Cruz
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a proposal to create an I-Corps Site at the University of California - Santa Cruz (UC-SC). The proposal outlines a focused summer program of eight weeks targeted at the under-represented population of the university. NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

Particular strengths of the proposal include: offering the I-Corps curriculum during a summer program that is well articulated; targeting under-served students in a region with potential for significant impact; an unusual mix of social, not-for-profit startups with for-profit ones; a strong collaboration with the Bay Area I-Corps Node; the commitment from the university to support the I-Corps focused activities; and, there is likely to be an impact not only on the region but also on the students, 25% of who are Hispanic. This project could potentially serve as a model for others to replicate.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Our Project "Accelerating Innovation and Entrepreneurial Development at University of California, Santa Cruz (UCSC)" created an innovation and entreneursship ecosystem at UCSC, a university with no business school and that previously had no such infrastructure.  This ecosystem included creating an incubator space (Slug Works) for student-led teams with technical tools needed for their innovations, designing and offering skills-based deep technology classses to student innovators, providing support to build a robust hackathon (Cruz Hacks), Pitch Competition (Launchpad), and student-lead entrepreneurship club (SCEE), launching a new innovation and entrepreneurship certificate program through Corwn College comprised of course that lean heavily on the NSF I-Corps lean launchpad curriculum, and expanding to sustainable entrepreneurship and innovation through collaboration with Rachel Carson College.  Morever, the program provided financial, training and mentorship support to over 200 student teams for their innovations and customer discovery. This program was transitioned to an on-line platform, including the skills-based classes, during the COVID-shutdown.  The intellectural merit of this project was the creating of an entrepreneurial ecosystem at UCSC based on best practices learned over the course of the grant period.  The broader impact was providing entreneurial training to students who can now take the skills learned and apply them successfully in their work place, or in a start-up, to accelerate the transition of innovations to the market place, or accelerate early failures so they can pivot faster to projects with greater potential.   


Last Modified: 10/07/2024
Modified by: Sue A Carter

Our Project "Accelerating Innovation and Entrepreneurial Development at University of California, Santa Cruz (UCSC)" created an innovation and entreneursship ecosystem at UCSC, a university with no business school and that previously had no such infrastructure. This ecosystem included creating an incubator space (Slug Works) for student-led teams with technical tools needed for their innovations, designing and offering skills-based deep technology classses to student innovators, providing support to build a robust hackathon (Cruz Hacks), Pitch Competition (Launchpad), and student-lead entrepreneurship club (SCEE), launching a new innovation and entrepreneurship certificate program through Corwn College comprised of course that lean heavily on the NSF I-Corps lean launchpad curriculum, and expanding to sustainable entrepreneurship and innovation through collaboration with Rachel Carson College. Morever, the program provided financial, training and mentorship support to over 200 student teams for their innovations and customer discovery. This program was transitioned to an on-line platform, including the skills-based classes, during the COVID-shutdown. The intellectural merit of this project was the creating of an entrepreneurial ecosystem at UCSC based on best practices learned over the course of the grant period. The broader impact was providing entreneurial training to students who can now take the skills learned and apply them successfully in their work place, or in a start-up, to accelerate the transition of innovations to the market place, or accelerate early failures so they can pivot faster to projects with greater potential.
